of Light," It was a little better and a little more practical than the generality of his sermons. I regret very much that he is going to leave Turin this Spring. I fear that we shall not be able to get another minister who will wholly fill his place. But we should not think too much of those things. He is only a servant and we should not look so much to the servant as to the Master. - I have just been to supper and have had the usual talk about the sermon which has not left me in a very pleasant mood to finish this letter so I hope you will excuse  me if it is not very interesting

    Our thaw which commenced the evening before you went home  has not terminated yet; but it has been raining more or  less all day. 
    Mr. Foot's little girl is very sick.
Completed

with brain feaver and her recovery is considered very doubtful. Her  father also is somewhat sick  but has no feaver. The case of this little girl creates a good  deal of anxiety among the school girls af. Mr. Northam's little girl died so sudden, as she also  was attending school here. We miss Mr. Foot very much when he is not at the Sabbath School as he is so efficient as a Superintendant and so universally liked. Has Jennie sent for the Atlantic Monthly yet? Wm has just brought in a copy of the Jan. No. which he borrowed to read. So if she gets the Jan No She need not send it  to me and I can read this,  I have purchased the 2nd vol of "The American Conflict" Is not the Cen. out yet? I have not seen it. Hoping none of our folks are sick 
Write Soon,            Eddie
Completed

4 A.M.          
   Turin Aug. 7th, 1867 

Dear Friends,                

If I were not too sleepy I would write you a few lines, but - I will try.  I expected to come down Mon. morning, first train. A friend of mine from here, Mrs.  Rockwell, is going out to  Middleton, Conn. and wishes to go with us as far as Springfield if we go that way. I have not seen  her but her daughter spoke  to me about her going. I expect to see her before  I start so as to make
Completed

arrangements as to when  to start. She wishes to  start on the P.M.  train Mon. or Tues. She is a very pleasant old lady and will be good company for us.        

 We had installation last - evening and elected H.C. Northam W.C.T. Mrs C. G. Riggs W.V.C.T. &c. We are prospering finely Our degree lodge numbers 71 and our sub. lodge 238 in good standing.   
   If anything occurs that the girls cannot  go as agreed let me know as soon as possible. I send this note
Completed

with Wm. He will probably return tomorrow  P.M. I am looking forward to next week with high expectations. I am afraid I shall not see Mr. Parsons who I  understand is coming  about the 14th inst. though he may stay til I get back.  Cynthia, Mr. Eben. Jones of Constableville buried their little child  yesterday about 4 mos old.     

 Love to all in haste             
     EW Everett
Completed

Turin, N.Y. Nov. 3rd, 67               

My Dear Sister and all At Home                                    

   I was very glad to receive your letter after two weeks of silence on both sides and I guess  more on my part. It had really become a dread to me to think of writing home after neglecting you so long. In a measure I can make  your plea for not writing my  own i.e. press of business for during the last two weeks I have had more to do than was convenient for me to do. The new goods have been coming in and I had all the marking  and puting away to do, which left no time for correspondence. I promised Jennie
Completed

a letter, the last time I wrote  so before mailing this I must gather up the fragments of  that promise and write to her.      

 Anna I am glad that you  and Sarah got home so comfortably and that the visit East has done you so much good. Hope you did not have to walk from Worcester to the  Junction or have your trunk burst open at Springfield. I will always remember that trip with pleasure. Were it not for those sharp corners and rough edges which at the time  were unpleasant we should remember  so much about it. But who can forget Worcester Junction and Worcester after our experience! Or who can forget such a  White Mountain Excursion!! Hark! Who! Not I.      
 What a lovely fall we have had indeed summer too. It has been a model season
Completed

(if the expression is allowable) I have been expecting for the last  two weeks that each day was the last pleasant one of the series. But not until to day has the weather taken a decided  turn. To night it is cold  and wet and dark and it  is too near Election to expect more pleasant weather just now. We are to have a baloon ascension here next Thursday if it is fair weather or the first fair day thereafter Mr. Squires the baloonist is from Prospect, Oneida Co. and has made over fifty ascensions.      

  You say you wish I could come  home soon. I wish so too as I  have lots to talk about. But I do not know how soon I can come. I wish it was not so far so I could come home once in a while to spend the Sabbath I have not been to meeting to-day except S. School. It was so rainy tonight that we had
Completed

no meeting. I have given  up the charge of the library and now have a class. Pray  that I may be useful in this new enterprise In my class  are only three as yet - boys of about fifteen.    

 I was very sorry to hear that brother Johns' health is so poor, I wish I was out there with him. Hope he is well now. I will try to remember to enclose his letter  in this to return.            I attended a wedding  party last evening here in the place all but the wedding did not come off. But it probably will a week from  to-morrow. The gentleman is from the west and the lady has been living west some time and has lately come home on a visit and to be married. Her fellow has come but they are not  married yet as a good many suppose they would be last evening.  Love to you all from your brother E  

Please write soon again.
Completed

Turin, Nov. 21, 1867, 

My Dear Sister             

   Please pardon me for not answering your letter  sooner. No Excuse but business. I thank you for writing to me as you did. Your letter deserved a more prompt reply. Well, I do not know what to say. I am a little surprised but by no means disappointed. Trust it is all right. May God's blessing follow you.    
   I have no time to write  you a letter to=night but only a note. Isaac Prichard has been  in the store this evening. He is helping his brother William  move up near Martinsburg. We have a good Templars Co. Convention in Lowville next Tuesday and Wednesday. Hope I can go one day. We are  very busy every day in the store
Completed

Mrs. Williams handed me the enclosed last night and I  promised to send it last night  but forgot it Please have it inserted in the Cen. in the proper place if possible this next number.    

   All well. Much love to all from your        
    Brother Eddie
Completed

Turin, N.Y. Nov. 27th, 1867   

My Dear Sister                 

  I have long intended to write you a letter, which intention I am now going to promulgate. It is seldom that I hear from home now and they have not mentioned about you but once. I am anxious to hear how you are prospering in your new project. Hope you are well and  doing finely. When you receive this letter I hope you will sit down and answer  it. It must be very delightful in New York now. Wish I could be there with you. It would be so pleasant. To-morrow is  Thanksgiving. The annual return of that day always reminds me of home and absent friends. May it remind me more of that best of friends our bountiful Benefactor who has been so kind to us during the year - yes all our lifetime. I shall think of you to-morrow while this letter  is on its way hope you will think of  me and pray for me.
Completed
Completed

I feel guilty that I have not written to cosin Thomas. He was so kind to me when  I was in N.Y. and I have neglected to write so long - too bad! Well I will write  to him in a few days. Where are you boarding. I will direct this to his care as that is the best I can do. What is Coz. doing now? I am still with R.W. & F. but do not know how long I shall remain here. My time is up in about a week. Will probably stay here this winter.     
  We expect the cars will soon be running to the Falls regular There has been one train up to-day That is only three miles distant. They will not run any further this winter. William R. Jones (son of Robt. R. Jones Bethel) is going to be depot master there. I am going home when the passenger trains run up to the Falls. Hope I have got through staging  over the planks to Boonville     
  Have you heard Mr. Everett preach and if so how do you like him? if  not go and hear him next Sabbath I liked him very much. O how I wish  we had a pastor in our church. Give my love to cousins Thomas & Elisabeth and axcept the same yourself from Your Brother Eddie.
Completed

Turin, March 6th, 1868, 

My Dear Sister               

   Your letter bearing postmark of the 1st inst is  just received this P.M. This is the first mail we have had  since last Saturday. Your letters generally come through the same  day but this is unusual. We have about decided that we could live without the B.R.R.R. but it would be  decidedly inconvenient.    
   Your letter was doubly welcome as it had really a long time since I had heard a word from home and with four mails coming to-gether I surely expected one letter. I have been feeling somewhat sad and lonely to-day as it is the anniversary of brother Henry's death. I have been
Completed

thinking of him all day. Last night I sat up with the corpse of Mrs. Warren Jones, (perhaps you did not know her) and to-day attended the  funeral as one of the 'bearers.' I don't know when my mind has wandered back over the past as it has to-day. I wish I could be at home to-night. I wonder what you are all doing. Perhaps father has gone to prayer-meeting,  but I hope he is home if it storms as  it does here. Yesterday was the only pleasant day we have this week. Snow is about four and a half  feet deep and some pitch-holes are nearly as deep. I send you three studs same  as before and 2 sample pearl S. buttons 15c per. Doz. I do not  know anything about the fifteen
Completed

cents you say I lent you but of course I will keep  it if you say you owe it.  I remit the bal., 25 cents. Tell Sarah that if she ever get almost sick because I am neglected that I recomend a good dose  or writing materials, rightly put to-gether. I hope she will try it. This remedy is equally as god for well as for sick persons. Try it. I should like to see that new dress of yours. I am quite interested in your affairs. And whatever you see fit to communicate to my is read with interest.    

   I am sorry to know  that John is no better. I am afraid he is not enjoying himself much since he went back to Kansas. I must write to sister Elisabeth. I wish I could get you to write some
Completed

letters for me They are having a  Sociable at the G.T. Hall to-night. They have been  having them at the houses and this is the first at the hall. The object is to raise money to carpet the floor That will be done soon. We have a Cabinet Organ.  

   We have nothing now that would be pretty for whit aprons? now.   
  I think March can be said to have come in like  a lion this year. May it go out as much like a  lamb.    
 I must bid you all good night as I am very  sleepy. More annon Eddie
Completed

Turin, 10 April 1868 

Dear Friends at Home                     

  Perhaps you will look for me to=morrow as I mentioned something about it in my last, but owing to the fine sleighing we are having we are quite busy in the store and as I am the only clerk it  is difficult for me to leave just now. Will try to come next week. Pierce and Clara were here to=day They have gone back, on the hill. Expect to return home to=morrow. Love to all,          
   In haste                  
   E.W. Everett
Completed

Turin, May 29, 1868 

My Dear Sister               

 Your letter should have been answered sooner but I put you off thinking you would  care so much if I only wrote  to the other girls. It deserves a good letter in reply, but I fear that my attempt tonight will prove almost a failure. I wish I could have another  short visit with you soon. But fear I cannot come home yet - a while. O! you ought to have been here yesterday! we had one of the finest balloon ascensions I ever witnessed. There were a great many people in town which of course kept us very busy. I did not go up to the fair
Completed

grounds when the balloon was inflated but saw it from the  store. There was apparently  but very little wind, so it went up very nearly straight for one or two hundred feet and sailed off majestically directly north. Mr. Squires who made the ascension is the one who made an ascension at Lowville last fall. The balloon went directly over the village of Lowville and he landed just outside of the corporation. making the trip of eleven  miles in forty five minutes not very fast for an air ship but so nice and landing just where he wanted to.  

   We had a beautiful and refreshing rain this afternoon.
Completed

You write about the death of Jennie Griffths. I do not  remember her. I am ashamed  to say that I have forgotten some of those with whom I used to be quite well acquainted but I think it is partially owing to the fact that there are so many of the same name. Am sorry to hear that  Morris Griffiths and Griffith James are sick. But I hope they are both well ere this.      
  The cenhadwr came last eve. Guess our folks are smarter than they used to  be. Is cousin Ottie there yet? give my love to her and tell her I am coming out to Chicago to see her sometime. I saw the account in the Cen. of the marriage of Hugh and Mary Ann. Tell them
Completed

that when they get to keeping house I am coming down to see them. When are you and  Cynthia coming up to see your brother? Write me before hand if you can so that I may know when to expect you. Hope you will come soon while it is so pleasant. We have finally engaged a minister for four months. He is a student and has one year yet to attend school. I hope he is the right  man to do us good. I am expecting to hear often from home to know how you all are. Tell Anna I will try to write to her soon Hope she still continues  to gain      

    Yours with much Love,                  
      E.W. Everett
Completed

Turin, 16th July 1868, 

My Dear Sister                  

   I suppose you are "home again" and hope  you are well and feeling  refreshed after your visit I hope enjoyed your visit as well as I did, but I think we both would have enjoyed it better if I had been at liberty more to take you around You know  there are a good many  places that we intended to call but did not have time. I really wish I could return your visit and have a good visit with you all. Is Anna improving any?
Completed

I ought to write her a  letter. Will try to bear it in mind. Did you know that- Mrs. Bush died during the  night - before you left? She was buried yesterday afternoon at four o'clock. Last night we organized a Grant Club and are going to work for the campaign. Maj. J.M. Mascott is Pres. and L.J. Lewis Secy another item of news - the toll gate just this side of Houseville was burned last night. There was no one living in it the family that lived in it had just moved out. And the  family that were going  to move in have decided not to. It was probably
Completed

set on fire by some one and no one seems to feel very bad as the plank road is mizerable and the gate will probably never be rebuilt. The democrats lay it to the Grant Club, but we lay it to a committee from the "Cu Clux Clan." The telegraph was attached to one corner of the building and of course the wire was welded, and communication cut off so that The Turin Fire + Hose Co. could not be sent for.    

 We have got one front in all except the doors so I will have to bunk on the counter again to=night and will be up in the morning in time to mail this letter. Your mitts are here
Completed

I can not find them to night to send them.    

  We had a temperance lecture at our church this evening but I did not go. They say it was good, and pretty well attended.    
 I am anxious to know  what you hear from Mr. B. I trust it will be all right but I hope you wont worry  about it. Write soon and tell me how you got home and how you all do.       Love to all at home           
 from your brother                      
     Eddie
Completed

annotation 1860's /annotation

Tues. morn
Dear Sister   
  I received your letter last night. There was plenty of room for it in the carraige. But do not worry so about coming home. We would like  to have you go with us to the Society but we dont want you to hurry awfully for anything else. Hope Mary and Brannie (and we wish Ella) will come with you. Father says you had a letter get some money of Uncle. We hardly dare venture to
Completed

send any this morn for fear you will not get this before you come. We are getting about pretty well. We washed with lye water yesterday. I take care of Auntie nights and she is quite good Get us 1 pound of pulverized white sugar. Something brewing for the 4th. up to the big farm yesterday morning I wrote a  note to Rev. E.C. Curtis making  some inquiries relative to the most pressing needs of the wounded and also as to where it would be  best to send the box. Last night
Completed

I received as reply giving full directions as to where he thought was the  best place to send, also containing  other most interesting and valuable information. He advises at present to send to Fortres Monroe as that now is the best point  from which to forward supplies and will be, he says, until Grant takes Richmond I am  glad you heard that sermon  I hope you will not forget it all before you came home.  Eddie is shaving and must soon have this. Mary is milking alone
Completed

and I must hurry to help her. I help milk every day          

  Cynthia 

different hand
John W. Roberts has received his photograph which I mentioned about in the other letter, so you need not trouble yourself about it if you have not been there. How are they selling calico in Utica now. We are selling  for 2/. and 2/9, a nice time to buy a new calico dress.                   

   Eddie.
Completed

Remsen Aug 27th 

Dear Sisters Three & All,        

  I have but a  few minutes to spare, but will improve them in writing yo a few lines to apprize you of me safe arrival here to=day. I reached New York Sat. morn. Found Coz. Thomas in the afternoon and he spent all his time with me until I started home last night. I had a very pleasant time in N.Y. Visited the Park, (Central) Barnum's, Greenwood, Coney Island and had a
Completed

bath in the sea. I did not enjoy my visit in Boston much as it rained all the time. I am going to Turin to=night. Am feeling first rate, and hope you all do the same. Axcept much love Write to me soon I will leave this letter for somebody else to  finish.        

  In great haste.    
  From your brother          
    Eddie
Completed

Wed, Morn - We had Sarah's letter last eveg. - Were very glad to hear that Anna is getting along so
well - we are very busy with Cen.

        all well this morn.-

love to you all - Your Father
Completed

Turin, May 16, 1871.    
Dear Sister,       

   I have finally  got the table started. Sent it to the depot today and it will be in Remsen at the same time as this letter.    
 I called at William P. Williams; this afternoon and to my  surprise found Clara and little Lyman there. He is a fine boy but not as heavy as Carroll. Have you seen him? Where is Uncle Nathaniel now? We were very glad to have even  a short visit with him. Hope we shall see him again before  he returns. Hugh Lewis is no better. I fear it will be some time before he will be well
Completed

enough to be in the store again. We are having a  nice warm rain tonight. It is very much needed. We are all well. Hope Anna will make us a visit soon.  They have got all through painting  the house, and we are better prepared to entertain visitors than when you and Uncle were here.  

  Love to all                  
   Your aff. bro.                       
   Eddie.
Completed

Turin, July 15, 1871.    
Dear Friends,     
 We reached home all safe at six o'clock P.M. It may seem to you a good while to be on the road but I will explain. Our buggy was pretty well filled, you know,  and we had the small satchell in front of us and there was  nothing to prevent it sliding out so when we were looking at it the mischievous thing slid out, and we did not  miss it until we were near  Alder Creek, We went back about two miles and found it near Penygraig. No one having passed the spot since we did, it was on the middle of the road.
Completed

We reached Boonville about one. Staid three hours and took dinner and rested nicely . When I got to the store I was a little alarmed to learn that our store had been entered by a burglar on Thursday night but hapily he was frightened away without taking or disturbing anything. I was through a mere accident that Mr. Emmer? came to the store about twelve o'clock and as he entered the door he heard the noise of someone stepping  on the floor rear of the  store and at that moment his  hair assumed a virtigal position and he immediately retreated and closed the door but before he  could obtain any help the chap got out the same way he entered.
Completed

which was through the  cellarway of the adjoining store in front which was  very carelessly left exposed and the cellars being connected the thief gained egress to the store through our trap door. The next morning he was tracked across the road both coming and going until the same rubber tracks as were seen the morning after Mr. Whites' bonds were taken. I think there must be an  organized band of burglars about here or at least some persons in our place who are connected with such a gang. We are taking precaution that the above may not be repeated.    

 We are all well but rather tired. Will write
Completed

again soon,    

 Love to all at home    
  Eddie  

P.S. Did Lewis get all  his hay in today? Hope he had help enough to improve the good weather. I enclose a few samples and if any suit return the sample &c.                        E.W.E
Completed

Turin. May 8, 1876.
  Dear Sister
    Your Kind letter, with flour seeds for Mate from Anna, also the copy of those verses from Cynthia for which Mate is much obliged - I was going to say your letter was received Sat. eve. and I am going to answer it promptly this time. There is 9 yards more of that Blk. Cashmere. You can have just what you want of it as the rest will sell for sacks. Let me know at once so that I can bring it with me when I am on my way to New York. The potatoes are $2. per Bushel, so $1. s. worth would be 1/2 Bushel - that amount, if they are cut up and planted with 3 eyes in a hill will go a good ways. I will save the 40th
Completed

Maple Sugar for you, and if you want the potatoes, they could be packed together. If this pleasant weather continues a few days potatoes ought to be put in the ground this week. The prospects are that there will be feed for cattle in a week. I am glad you have got a new horse. What are you going to do with Lye?

    I was very sorry to hear of Elias Jones & Hugh Jones' sickness. Hope Hugh's life may be spared.
    I think of going to New York the last of this week or next Monday. William P. Williams is going today. Trade seems to be backward this spring but he have sold $1200. worth more during March and April this year than during the same months last year. That looks encouraging for the centennial this year
    In regard to that money. We want to have the land surveyed before
Completed

any more papers are made out so as to be sure that the bounderies are all right and the ground is not dry enough for that yet, but I would like to get the money before I go to New York. If I should come home Thursday could you let me have it? A draft on N.Y. would be the best. If you could do this and had as leave to do it as not I will stop off over night Thursday and go to N.Y. Friday morning
If you had rather wait until you get the papers do not be afraid to say so but I will see that you
get them all right within a month. Please write me as soon as convenient and let me know. 

    It is mail time.
                   In haste,
                             E.W.E.
Completed

Turin, Jan. 16, 1877,

Dear Brother + Sister,

    You will probably be somewhat surprised to receive a letter from me as you know I am not much of a hand to write but as I have a good excuse I will write a few lines although it is after 10 P.M. and I ought to be at home. I suppose our folks at home have written you that I made them a short visit. I was glad to find mother so comfortable after another of her sad accidents. It is remarkable that her general health is so good. She has the best of care and that accounts for her good health. It is fortunate that Mary was at home at the time of the accident and that she remains with mother.
Completed

I brought the enclosed letter from cousin Mary Ann Roberts home with me to read and  they have written me to send  it to you. We are sorry to hear that William is no better there than at Remsen. This is a severe winter and perhaps that has something to do with  it. Have you decided what you  will do next summer? I suppose you hardly know what will be best. Tell Hattie that we saw Mr. Nibecker for just a  few minutes at the close of  a temperance lecture at Turin a few weeks ago. He was here all day but I was out of town when he called at the store and so failed to see him until just before he started home. We were  very sorry that we did not
Completed

know of his being in town also that he did not call at the house as Mate was at home,     

  We have been having a series of revival meetings at the M.E. church for a number of  weeks past and upwards of 125 have turned their faces  heavenward and the churches have been revived. The meetings still continue. We hope that Abbie has met with a change of heart also many others of our friends.    
  We are all quite well.  We are not having as much snow on the Black River R.R. as they do on the Central and many other roads, but we think we have enough It rained for about an hour last  night - the first rain we have for 5 weeks. This morning every thing was coated with ice.
Completed

We would be very glad to hear from you and from Hattie and all. We send lots of love to you and shall expect to receive a letter soon. Carroll has got so he reads
a good many words. Both of the boys are very fond of going to Sunday School. Charlie has a new way of asking for what he wants but he finds that it is generally
sucessful. He says, Mama, I cant have any apple, can I? or I cant have any cookie, can I? He always gets it. I must close now and go home. Your younger brother
Eddie.
Completed

Turin, July 14/77, Dear Sister & all This afternoon when I was about to put up a bottle of Asthma Specific to my surprise I found none. When you wrote for it there 
was several bottles, but it is all sold. and I am very sorry as I know William is expecting it tonight after the card I wrote this morning. I think he had better send to Dr. Kingsley for two or three bottles as need to have it on hand whenever he is worse. Mr. D.W. Roberts + wife are
Completed

expecting to go to Remsen by first train Monday to attend the funeral of her father. I suppose you are expecting Jennie this evening. Wish we could be there to meet
her. Is not Mary coming with her? If Jennie comes tonight cannot you make us a visit next week and stay until we go back with you. I wish you could. In great haste. Your brother, E.W.E
Completed

Wednesday morning.There seems to have been a succession of blunders about this bottle of medicine, and most of the blame is with me. This letter was sent to Remsen with Mr. Lewis and I told him that probably you would send to Mr. Richards for the medicine and to leave the letter there. He forgot to leave it and returned it to me yesterday morning. The best way for you now is to send to Rome for the med. I have not been very well for two or three days. but am some better this morning. I shall expect to hear from home oftener now Jennie is
Completed
home. I hope she is feeling much better after her trip. Shall expect a letter from her soon.Your brother Edward
Completed

Turin Aug 11/77, Dear Friends, We had a fine ride home and found them all well and waiting to see us. Charlie slept most of the way. I send a package by mail to Carroll. I left my gold pen and wish you would send the pen without the holder by mail as I miss it every day. The steam boat L.R. Lyon was burned at Lyons Falls yesterday morn. with two lives lost. Hope Carroll will be a good boy and not trouble you. Tell him there are two little boys living in the same home as Bertie Hughes about the ages of 4 + 6.  E.W.E
Completed

POSTAL CARD                                    U.S. POSTAGE

        US                                                  {IMAGE}
                                                              ONE CENT
WRITE THE ADDRESS ON THIS SIDE-THE MESSAGE ON THE OTHER

                       Miss Jennie Everett
                                 Remsen
                                        N.Y.
Completed

Turin, Aug. 13/77. Dear Friends, Charlie is so lonesome without Carroll that he can hardly wait for him to come. He has written two letters, one for Carroll and one for Aunt Anna and then had to read them over in this way, - "Carroll come home," "Aunt Anna come home, Please. Carroll come home. When he woke up yesterday he said "I wish I was in Remsen," I asked him what he would do if he was there. He said he would bring them all home with him, mentioning each one by name.
Completed

The rest of us are well. Mother Allen went home yesterday. Abbie is enjoying Fannie's Visit - very much, and so are we all. We shall expect cousin Mary and Anna & Carroll before the end of this week. Wish Mother might come with them. If she should conclude to, you must be sure to let us know when to expect you. Accept love from us all.
Your - E. W Everett
Completed

Turin, June 21, 1878, 
Dear Sisters, 

  Mr. J.T. Jones paid me $8. today the amount due for cenhadwr as per bill. Shall I send it by P.O. order or wait until I see some of you? Have you seen Elizabeth Owens and exchanged that note? Is it satisfactory with her? The store remains closed yet. Do not know how soon it will be opened. I have had a good, long vacation. Mate thinks there is some small gain resulting from this trouble. She has had my help to take up and shake carpets, put them down again. Take down the coal stove and lots of other chores too numerous to mention. The dining-room, bed room and
Completed

kitchen have been cleaned and the carpet on the dining room has been washed this week, and now, I believe the house-cleaning is done for this season. We have
been down to Mother Allen's visiting today. Have you got the spring beds and if so how do they fit. Those I sent are 48 inches wide. Remember if you have a chance to sell any that there are some of widths as follows, 36 inch for single bed, 46 inch. 50 inch & 52 inch. but the 48 inch is used mostly. C.H. Owens + Co are closing out their stock of goods at cost for cash. They are going out of business. Carroll has but two weeks more of school this term. He has not missed a day yet this term. Have you heard anything more from Hillsdale? I hope we shall have a letter from you tonight.
Completed

Sat. Morn. - No letter from home last eve. so I send this sheet as it is. I had left room to answer a letter in case one came in last night's mail.
We had a fine shower in the night with prospects of more rain today. We are all well and all send love.Your brother. E.W. Everett.
Completed

Turin, March 1, 1879, 
Dear Sisters, 
Robbie wrote us last Monday that he was to be married Wednesday and that they intended driving to Turin to spend a day or two with us but as it was so stormy we did not much expect them. Have heard nothing from them since. Did Owen come home? Robbie expected him. Has he completed his course? Have you done any thing with those accounts yet? Has Jennie sent you any blanks yet? I expect to be in Remsen, Monday the 10th inst. and will then plan the trip &c. Has Henry Parry, Port Leyden paid his bill? I want to collect those around
Completed

her and in Boonville before I start if I can. I have not heard from N.Y. for two weeks. Have written them last - suppose they are both busy. We are all well. When I last wrote you I sujested that you make us a visit. Have not heard from you since The saying is that silence gives consent. You must come soon if you expect to find me here. We want to go to Lowville next to have our likeness taken before I go. Love to you all from your brother. Edward.
Completed

Turin, April 12, 1879. 
Dear Sister, 

 Your letter was rec'd last eve. It seems that you do not think as Anna does about postponing for a while my collecting trip. If it would not defer my trip but two months or so, and if you could manage the financial front without collecting first, I would think that it would be best to wait. As for myself it will make no difference as I can go now or I can have work here in the store for the present and go in June or July. I think that it is a poor time to collect in any of the states except this state and Ohio and perhaps Penn. but as for the Western states
Completed

they have no money and they pay nothing at present, but if they should have good crops this summer it would be a favorable time to visit them in July or August, or later. I want to hear again from Anna before I start and I would like to hear also from you. I shall wait at least a few days now before starting. How long will it be before the cofiant can be ready for sale? What will the price be? I send the bill for John Eddie's board and what I paid out for him. If correct please give me credit for the amount of the bill on rent. I have collected the $6.50/100 balance from D. Thomas int. on mort. and will send you check the first of the week.
Completed
The snow is quite deep here yet. Very little maple sugar has been made yet. Shall hope to hear again from you soon. With love to you both, Your brother Eddie.
Completed

Turin, April 25. 1879, Dear Sister It is a long time since I have heard a word from any of you, and when I wrote you last I thought I should see you before this. Have you heard anything from Jennie lately? I had two cards from her about ten days ago saying she was perfectly willing for me to wait until the cofiant was published and in both cards she promised to write me a letter again soon but it is a good while coming. Do you know how long it will be before the it is expected to have the cofiant published? I wish I
Completed

could see you all. We have had a long winter and no visiting back and forth except what John Eddie has done. We have missed him very much since he has left us. How does he enjoy farming? Does he intend to do any of plowing this spring? I was over in Greig yesterday. They have commenced plowing there and that accounts for the above mistake The snow has disapeared remarkably fast from out streets this week. In many places it is dry ground. The sugar season appears to be nearly over. Carroll has been down to his uncle Jimmie's for over a week making sugar &c. He came home yesterday! His school commences next Monday. Can you get to the village with a wagon yet? I suppose
Completed

the snow is nearly gone there as well as here. How is William's health? Is Sarah pretty well. Do they intend to make butter or send milk to the
factory this season? The prospect of getting a high price is not flattering for either. In fact there is no business in which the prospect in flattering
just now. But we have got to make the best of the situation and trust in Providence. We are all well and send love to you all. Tell J.S. to drop us a card with his autograph if nothing more. Write soon to your brother Edward.
Completed

Turin, April 28, 1879. 
Dear Sister, 

  I received a card from you dated 15 April and another dated 16 April both promising a letter soon and I have been quite surprised in not getting a letter, - but today I received your letter of the 17th inst. it having been sent to the dead letter office for the want of a stamp. I suppose you have been equally surprised in not hearing from me but this letter which came Via Washington explains matters.

I was very sorry to hear of the sad accident which befell the lady at Mary's, and the final result. You speak of having the Gompers? font sent to N.Y. &c. If you could set it at Mary's without there being too much
Completed

expense in the type to N.Y. and from your rooms to the electrotyper &c. I should think it would be quite a saving. I think I had better go to some of the nearer places to see what can be done in collecting. I want to see Anna so as to talk with her about the collecting and about the Cofiant and I think I will visit them now in a few days and if Anna thinks best I will go to some, at least of the places in this state before I return to Turin, and then if thought best I can wait for the Cofiant before going farther. The snow is all gone from our streets - it went in about ten days without any rain. The grass is beginning to look green in places. It is surprising how abruptly our winter has
Completed

terminated. Sleighing commenced with the great snowfall on Dec 23 last when we had a fall of about three feet in 24 hours, and we have had severe winter weather with good sleighing for nearly four months, but when winter loosened her grasp spring has commenced in earnest. The roads are nearly settled. We are all well. Mate is busy cleaning house. Carroll commenced going to school again today. With much love to you 
both. Your brother Edward
Completed

Remsen, May 12, 1879    

Dear Sister,    

  I came to Remsen last Friday and am starting out this A.M. on a trial trip collecting. I am going to Otsego and Madison counties and possibly to Marcellus Falls, Onondaga Co. I do not know as it would be best to go to Middle Granville &c. or not but do not think I will go there now. There is about $275. in that section. Perhaps I can tell better after going to the other places mentioned. I ought to be ashamed of myself for not answering your last letter. The  first of last week I had my garden ploughed and had to carry off the usual  amount of stones and the planted some potatoes and sowed some peas. I worked hard to get this work done before leaving home and naturally gained a good or
Completed

rather fierce appetite and the result was that I was very sick that night and it has taken me  nearly a week to regain my strength I have had a good visit with the folks at home. I brought Charlie  with me and leave hime here until  my return. Mother Allen is staying with Mate and Carroll is at school. Mate is making rag=carpet and cleaning house. Anna and Sarah are both better than when I last saw them William is having quite a poor spell. They have had Griffith Jones here to help with the work I Eddie planted potatoes Saturday. I do not think it is advisable for me to think  of getting a place in  N.Y. to work at present. What would I do with my family? I do not lose my place in the store at Turin by being gone for two or three weeks now and I do not know as I can do better than go back to work there
Completed

for the present. I cannot afford to lose much time just now without earning something. If you think of anything better I  will be glad to have you sudjest.     

 I hope I may get some name for the Cofiant while on this trip but cannot expect to do very much without something to show. Have you decided to have it printed in N.Y. It seems to me that if you can stand it to set the type that you could manage it nicely if you had Anna there to read proof.     
Write me at Remsen for a week or two as I cannot tell where I could get a letter on my trip.     
 With much love to you both                   
 Your brother Edward.
Completed

Turin. July 7, 1879    

Dear Sisters,      

 I had written to Mr Griffiths and enclose you his reply which was received in company with your letter Saturday evening. I would like to have you decide on type &c. and write me as soon as possible so that I can answer Mr. Griffiths. if you wish me to do so. I do not see as the basis of his figure at this time differs materially from the other estimate only that they would of necessity be different on account of the difference in number of copies and having the paper furnished. I like the small price on account of its being the newest and cleanest looking.
Completed

If you wish me to write to him again I can then ascertain about preface &c. but as I understand it that is printed after the book or body of the book is printed as the contents cannot be prepared until the book is printed, and  the preface, title page contents &c. are printed the last thing. I  will also ascertain about the  size of the paper. Perhaps you will think best to go and see Mr. Griffiths but I do not think that is necessary. I mentioned in my letter to him that tinted paper would be furnished and asked whether it should be wet or not and he says not.  Has anything been done about portrait? Do you know how near the front of the book the
Completed

electrotype plate of short hand will come? That must be  attended to soon.     

 Carroll must have had a fine time on the 4th with firecrackers, fireworks &c. I hope he is not making his aunties much trouble. Charlie is lonesome without him. We all witnessed the fireworks here in the evening They were very good. There was a horse killed on the street here that evening be too men driving fast and coming in collission so the end of the shaft struck the other in his brest and entered the heart. Cause, intemperance    
 Charlie says we are going  to Remsen this week but I do not see how it can be done.  Guess we better not make any promises.
Completed

It is time for me to go to breakfast so I will close with love to you all and especially to Carroll.

                Your brother
                       Edward.
Completed

Turin, July 14, 1879.    

Dear Sister      

 I enclose letter recd. from T. J. Griffiths Sat. eve. It would be just as well for him to but the paper if he buys just such paper as we should select. If you get any sample that you think is just right, Perhaps it would be well to write to him to send for samples. I will write to him to send me samples of tinted paper such as he  thinks would be right.  We are all well. I sent that copy of John's letter to Mary. Why don't Carroll write? In Haste. Eddie.
Completed

Turin July 15th, 1879    

Dear sister Sarah Carroll + All      

  I thought as I had a little time before the mail went out I would drop you a line. Charlie wonders every day how J.E. + Carroll gets along with the haying he does not say quite as much about going to Remsen he seems to be quite contented now playing with Birtie? every day. I wonder if Carroll is'nt almost ready to come home? We want to see him very much Mrs. Ler was inquiring for
Completed

him Sunday. I think I did not put in only  one pair of every day stockings Edward says he will send him a cheap pair as they will be lighter than his homemade kinds. Yesterday after washing Charlie + I went out back of here and picked Raspberries enough for tea they were nice. Tell John E. that Clark Raney had a quarter of an acre of straberries vines and made $50 dollars isn't  that pretty will? How did his hat fit and does he wear it? Last Wednesday I was 32 years old and C+I spent the day at mothers had
Completed

a beautiful boquet for my birthday preasant  from Mrs. I? in the morn. Edward is quite well now has it a little  easier just now. Mr. Lewis is getting better although his cough is very bad. It is now past eight and Charlie has just getting up and I shall have to go and dress him hoping you can make out to read this as I have  written in a great  hurry. Charlie sends his love to all the aunties Carroll + J.E. 

 With love to all   
I am as ever your  
mother + sister
Completed

Turin, Oct. 4, 1879.   
My Dear Sister,       
Your letter came Thursday eve but I did not have  time to answer it yesterday morning.  The reason you got two buckets is that I sent to Eams + Bridgman Constableville by postal to send you one and hearing in nearly a week that you had not rec'd it. I bought one of one of the men traveling with pumps as I met him on the road thinking they had not sent the one I ordered. I wonder if you all enjoy this pleasant grand, fall weather as much as we do. Yesterday Mate + Charlie went  with me as I was going out on business. She spent the
Completed

afternoon at her cousins about three miles north of her mother's and returned about 8 o'clock P.M. The ride + visit did her lots of good and Charlie too. I cannot come home today but will try and visit you sometime next week. I am afraid you do not intend to  visit us at all this fall as you have not mentioned it lately in your letters. Mate  and all of us feel quite disappointed  but hope you may come yet. The boys are delighted  with the thought of having a  bbl. of apples from Remsen, And  so are the older ones. We have not rec'd them yet.                

   Your brother                 
     Eddie
Completed

Turin, Oct. 9, 1879,   
Dear Sisters      
 Your letter has just been received. Mate is some better than when I wrote you the card. She rested well the last two nights. She has not dressed her since or sit up since Monday. We have reason to hope she will now continue to improve. Her mother will stay with her until she is up again. We were very sorry to hear of the death of Mrs. Pugh. She will be greatly missed in the church as well as in her home, and  indeed in a large circle of society.    
 I forgot to mention that we had received the bbl. of apples.
Completed

She came Saturday. They were all very nice. Mate especially  enjoys the apples + pears now she is sick. And we all  enjoy them. I am glad you intend to visit us before you go into winter quarters as Mate would be quite disapointed  not to see some of you again before winter. I hope Mate will be well enough soon so that I can visit you.  

   Hope Hattie will make us a visit on her return in Nov. I must close now as they will be waiting for as they will be waiting for me to breakfast. Love to you all, from your brother    
        Edward
Completed

Turin, Oct. 16, 1879,    

Dear Sisters,       

Your letter and the engraving were received Tues. eve. also in the same mail  we received a letter from Mary + Anna, I only had time  yesterday morning to write a few words in a card. We think the engraving is very good. I should have liked it better if the back ground had been a little lighter. I return  it by this mail. I am sorry the memoir is so large. It cannot be sold  for $1. I fear. I suppose it will be difficult to exclude much of the remaining copy.  When is mother's engraving
Completed

to be ready? I think it would be well to have 100 copies of father's engraving  printed on paper.   

   Mate sit up about half an hour yesterday afternoon. This is the first time she has sit up since a week ago last Monday. She has been gaining slowly for the past four days. I think she will get along now without any more trouble is she is careful. The bbl. of apples has not come yet. Expect it will come today. How is Sarah's cough? When  do you think you will make us a visit? I hope Mate will be so that I  can visit you soon. With lots of love. Your brother                              
  Eddie.
Completed

Dear Sister- I am sending 2 Bot. Med. to  William this A.M. by Express. If he don't use but one I can bring the other back sometime. The Med. did not come in time to send it by those going to the Meeting. I was waiting for a chance to send it. We are very sorry to hear that poor Cynthia is no better and suffering so much.  If she could only talk it would be a comfort to  her and to her friends. Mate + the children a spending a few days at her mother's. Abbie is keeping house for me. We are all well. Write often, to Your Brother E.W.E.
Completed

Dear Sisters     

  I did mean to answer your letter before and tell  you all about the missionary meeting. I had Thursday to get ready for it as it was to be on Thursday. I  made arrangements for 25 or 30 Wed. eve I went out to invite some of my neighbors my head felt very bad in the morn. I awoke covered with a rash it rained all day only a few came all went home but two & these his

top margin:
price we have had a small piece just for a taste The boys had some down to Uncle J- have got the cubberds cleaned & trunk and drawers one good job done hoping to hear from you soon  lovingly your sister M.A. Everett

had it. The baby came out  with a rash the next morning. The boys and Edward have not had it Robbie grows every day seems to know what I say to him I was sitting  in the sitting room yester afternoon was fixing  over his lace bonnet I ask him to bring me the scissors he brought them  and then I said will you get me a stick of wood not thinking he knew what I meant he started for the kitchen and came draging a stick of wood to me I am making his lace bonnet larger Mrs. Kent has not been here to clean any yet. They expect  Maggie & Clara the last of this

get me two yards of chambray like the sample for baby a dress it washes good and write me the cost of goods & sending I am going to make some kicknack for unclearing The boys commenced Monday to go to school The hens enjoy being out every day we two one day & three the next and our old hen has commenced her old trail wanting to set I think we will kill her if she acts like that when are you coming  home Jule Clark has made his onion bed do you expect  J.E. soon Mrs. Drier is very sick not expected to get well hope you all are enjoying? yourselves very much our soft watt mens?? in

welk. George + Jennie House have bought out S.D. Noble and are busy getting things ready to butcher. Mrs. White has rented her house and  is moving a mile out of  the village. the sink more and we are to blame if we are not clean. We heard to-day that Davis "printer was dead. The roads are getting very good now not a great deal of sugar is made this spring it is sold for 15 cents. Would you like to have E get you some at that

Turin,  Aug 21, 1874
Dear Brother & Sister,
We have been looking for you this week, as you promised you would come out to see us as soon as haying was over, and we think you must be through by this time.  I wrote to Mary to see if she could not come up to see us while she is home.  Perhaps you could come up together, and if you do I should like very much to take you over to Brantingham Lake.  We could have a delightful time.  I am not very busy now and could spare the time now better than after returning from New York.
Completed

The farmers about here are through haying and are now busy with harvesting.  The grain crop and every other crop is very good this year.
We are all well excepting that Mate has had a toothache all night.
Love to all stage has come.
Your brother
E.W.E.
Completed

Plymouth,  July 28, 1881
Dear Sister,
I have just finished at this place.  The work has been slow here owing to difficulty in getting a guide, but it has been quite satisfactory.  This is a large Welsh settlement and it is impossible to do much work except after 5 P.M. as most of the men are in the works and do not come home to dinner.  Of those on my list of debtors for cen. there are three who have moved away, three have died.  But I have collected $24 out of the list and $12 more will be paid within three months.  I have sold 25 copies.  The men in these works are paid every month and when I have a good man to go with me who knows who is and is not responsible
Completed

I sell the book on one or sometimes two months time and leave it to be paid in to some one to send in.  I have sold more here than I expected and therefore am short of books.  Have but 7 books with me now.  Am going to Wilkes Barre now where I expect to receive 50 books tonight or tomorrow from Utica.  I shall go to Nauticoke from there and thence to Danville before going to Providence.  Will be at Danville the first of next week.  I received a letter from Mate today which was the first I had heard from her in two weeks.  I suppose there are two of her letters awaiting me at Scranton.  Write me at Danville.  I will send you a check $8.66 which I received on the old debt.  Please endorse it correctly Jennie Everett Executive of the Estate &c.  I called at the bank to get it cashed and they told me it was perfectly
Completed

good but I could not get it cashed because I did not have power of atty to sign your name in writing.  I was very glad to get your letter at Wilkes Barre written the 22.  I do not intend to go to Pittsburgh on this trip.
I am anxious to hear how Sarah is getting along.  Hope to hear that she is riding out regularly again and that she expects to be ready when I return to go to Brantingham.  We are having beautiful weather.  Have not bought or needed an umbrella yet.  I got me a thin coat & another linen vest.  I wrote the above at the depot at Plymouth while wating for the train.  Have just arrived at Wilkes Barre.  I enclose a P.O. Order for $40.
I am quite well.  I took dinner with Rev. Mr. Jarrett at Plymouth Tuesday and had a very pleasant call there again.
Completed

this A.M.  He left Collinsville with his family the same week that I left Turin.  Of course he and his family were glad to see any one from Lewis Co.  One of the little girls remarked "I wish some one from Collinsville would come here every day to dinner".
With much love to each of you from your wandering brother.
Edward.
Completed

Centralia,  Aug 4, 1881
Dear Sister,
I wrote you a card about a week ago to enquire about R.R. Tickets to the west during this time of Railroad war, requesting an answer to Danville.  I did not receive any mail at Danville, and knowing that the low prices for fare cannot continue long I enclose herewith a P.O.Order for twenty dollars and I will state my plan and want you to use your own good judgment in the matter.  I see by the papers that some of the roads are selling tickets at regular price but with a rebate so as to make the real fare from N.Y. to Cincinnatti only $7. and from N.Y. to Chicago $7. and from N.Y. to St. Louis $10.75 &c but I have not
Completed

seen account of reduction to any points west of St. Louis.  I intend to go home in about two weeks and thought by getting a ticket from N.Y. to Cin. I could go to the Vermont slate quarries with the Cofiant and thence to N.Y. and thence to Cin. Ohio.  And then I might use the other tickets (if I got two) to go to St. Louis, Mo & visit the Welsh settlements in Mo. and in Kansas and visit John and my other relatives in Kansas.  I suppose these tickets would be as good as any and good for one year.  I want you to buy me a ticket to Cincinnatti O. $7.  and one to St. Louis, Mo.  $10.75.  The price may have changed a little, up or down, but I want you to use your own judgment and keep the tickets at present.  Get the St. Louis ticket over the central if you can or over the Erie if you cannot over the
Completed

Central.  Possibly you can let some one use it as far as Utica as I would not want to use it from N.Y.  The P.O. Order is on Station E. which I believe is your station.  Please write me at Slatington or to Providence.  Will be at the former about the 9th and latter about the 12 or 13th inst.  I am doing quite well.  Am on the second Hundred of the Cofiant.  Am quite well and enjoying my trip.  I go to Shenandoah this P.M. thence to Mahavoy City.  Have heard nothing from home for a week  Expect to hear when I get to Hazleton tomorrow.
With much love from your brother
E.W. Everett
P.S. -- If the tickets only cost $7 and $10.75 = $17.75 you will have money left but the price may vary.
E.
Completed

Turin,  Dec 4, 1881
Dear Sisters,
As Carroll and Charlie have written each a letter I will write a little to send with theirs.  It is just 17 years today since I came to Turin to work.  There have been a great many changes since then.  Although I have not been as successful as I expected yet I have more things to be thankful for than to find fault or complain about.
The boys are very much pleased with their Youth's Companion..  I hope they will make good use of them.  They are now anticipating
Completed

a great deal of pleasure at Christmas tree.  There are to be two here as usual, one at each church.
I am so glad you have got those blinds up.  Hope you can keep the parlor warm and comfortable now in the coldest weather.  What is the down comfortable you spoke of Jennie on your card?  How is it made.  I have just bought a new matress for $4 for the bed in the sitting room.
We are all well as usual and send love.
Edward.
Completed

Turin,  Jan 15, 1882
Dear Sister,
I have sent the deed to Mr. Winston as requested.  I had ascertained the amount of tax against the premiums but had done nothing more.  I have had too much to attend to at home to do that business.
I went to see Sarah last Wed. returning the same day.  I found Sarah very low indeed.  She seemed quite anxious to see you -- not so much that she thought you could do anything for her but that she wanted to see you.  I received a card from Jennie last eve saying the were looking for you, but I send this to N.Y. lest you may be detained from coming.  I wish we could see you
Completed

when you come, but suppose you would not feel like sparing the time.  Do not know as it would be as well for Sarah to have us both there the same day.  I fear Sarah will not last long she is so very weak and takes so little nourishment.
Mate is getting along quite well although she does not gain strength as fast as she wishes she could.  She takes the entire care of the baby.  We weighed little Robert Allen this eve and found that he weighs 12 1/4 lbs.  He is a healthy boy and is growing fat.  The other boys are quite well and improving their time in school.  We all send love
Your brother
Edward
Completed

Turin, N.Y.  Jan 24, 1882
My Dear Sister,
We were quite disappointed in not receiving a word from some of you tonight to know how our dear sister has been today but I know your time is limited as well as mine.  It is after 12 P.M. and the rest of the family are in sweet repose but I must write you tonight as I do not have time in the mornings except for a hasty card.  Our girl is not coming back and we must look up another one.  Carroll and I do what work is done about the house (except the care of little Robert) as Mate is not strong enough to do much out of her room.  She was feeling quite poorly this morning as the room got a little to cool during last night
Completed

but she is feeling better tonight.  Her tooth has not troubled her much for a day or two.  Do not know as it will answer to have it extracted while she is so weak.  I enclose the check received for the John Evans note.  I have made statements of the accounts as seems best to me but you need not use them unless you think they are better than the others.  You will notice that I have omitted the words.  "Received Payment" as you will need to go before a notary public or a Justice of the Peace and make affidavit to the papers that the account (& note) is correct and not paid &c.  I do not know but it will be necessary to make a copy of the endorsements also which are on the note but do not think it necessary.  I endorse the note Jane received about Morgan Edwards and Maggie says Nelson is his address
Completed

He did not send pay.  I think you better send him a book and a bill for the same.  I ought to go there in the spring.  Is Mary still with you?  I hope she is as it will be very hard for you to spare her, but I know it is very hard also for her to be away from her business so long.  I fear this intense cold weather has had a bad effect on Sarah.  It is very trying for those in health but what must it be for her!  Hope you will succeed in keeping the room of an even temperature.  Where does the bed stand now?  What nourishment does she take now?  How is her month?  Does she talk less or more than when I saw her last?  I wish very much I could be with you more but how can I?  When we get a girl I will try to come down again.  There is a great deal said about us here about the necessity of vaccination and I presume it will be made
Completed

compulsory in our village upon those who have not been vaccinated within a certain length of time.  Our boys have never been vaccinated.  Has Mary any vacceen with her that is all right?
I must close now and retire and hope for a word from you tomorrow (Wednesday) and every night as we feel very anxious.  With much love to you all and especially to Sarah from us all.
Your brother,
Edward
Completed

Turin Jan. 26th, 1882 Dear sisters Have just rec'd Jennies and Anna's letters. Carroll & Charlie went for the mail as Edward did not go back to the store after tea. I have just got Edward in bed after soaking his feet and giving him a hot cup of tea he is sweating nicely now, he took some cold yesterday and day before he came home last night feeling chilly said he thought he would feel all right in the morning. he was uneasy all night and and restless
Completed

this morn. felt better and went to the store he came home to tea tonight feeling chilly now he is sweating nicely in bed. Jennie went in search of a girl to-day for us. we have got along nicely so far I have not ventured in the kitchen much till to-day. we live mostly on oatmeal & milk & rice baked apples &c. I would like very much to go to Remsen & see Sarah and you all. it seems a long time since I have seen any of you. hope E can go soon. am so glad Caroline is there with you and also
Completed

John E. I think of you often. The baby is very good. I think we will call him Robbie as S spoke of. The boys are a great help. I sometimes think Carroll does as well as Libbie only he can't wash. he did iron a Little for me the other day. we have not taken the baby up in the night since since Caroline went away. We are very glad to hear from you nearly every day. was glad that Mary could come home for a short time. it must be a great
Completed
comfort to you all with  a great deal of love to you all and especily to Sarah the dear child I will bid you all good night. From sister Mate
Completed

Upper Sandusky, Ohio, Aug 25 /84. Dear Sisters & All. I am now on my way from Venadocia to Radnor, 7 mi north of Deleware. I have to wait here two hours to make connections. Venadocia is a right smart place to raise corn, wheat pork &c, and there a great many good people there, but from my observation I should say it is a better field for selling "Cofiant Dr. Rowlands" "Rhodd Main" &c than those for my business. I was aware of this before going out but found it more so than I expected. I would not have been so anxious to go there but I wanted to see Wm. Williams Delphon formerly who owed $16. But when I found him he claimed
Completed

that he had not received the Cen. but for one year after coming from Cincinnatti & that he had paid in advance for that year. Probably some other Wm. Williams got it from the P.O. So I did not make any collections at V. I sold 15 of the memoir and 6 of Uncle Lou at 30 cts. I collected $20 at Somer that would not be paid without going there for it. Have collected enough so far to pay my fare. I sent you a P.O.O. from Lima for $50. The 21st in a letter to Mate. I also enclose a P.O.O in this for $30. I received a P.O. from Mate dated the 18th, at V. That is all the mail I got there. Write me next at Columbus or Granville. Will be at Deleware over Sabbath. Please pay Rev. E. Davies $.160 which I received from Evan Evans, Somer,
Completed

for the Cen. for 1882 so that it may be acknowledged by him. If you think best you might have the enclosed notice inserted on the second page of next Cen cover. It may open the way for me in some places. In haste & with lots of love to Mate, the children & all. Your brother, Edward
Completed

Turin, Jan 24, 1883 at Home Dear Sisters, I have been sick with a cold and billious trouble as usual since Saturday P.M. was not out of the house Sunday and ought not to have been out Monday but was in the store until tea time. Since then I have not been out, but am much better this P.M. and hope to get out to the store tomorrow. This accounts for your not hearing from us sooner. We recd your letter Sat. eve. saying you expected to come this week & hope to see you before the Sabbath. Hope Anna will be very careful to not take more cold.  John Roberts is off on his wedding trip and Geo. Allen drives stage nearly altogether this week. We think you will find it warm & comfortable here when
Completed

you come. Carroll and Charlie are the only well ones we have now. Mate has had a cough for about three weeks. Her felon is about well.  Baby is not having the whooping cough very hard, if indeed he is having it at all. He coughs more nights than day times but is rather worrisome through the day. George is not staying here now. It has been quite stormy so far this week but we hope the last of the week will not be so. Please enquire of Joe Roberts if there is a box of books there for me from Newburgh, Ohio and pay the freight. We received a letter from John Eddie this morning containing the tintype of John and myself. also a photo of John E. & his father. I am thankful the former did not reach home before I did as it might have created some anxiety about my health. It seems to me that Tom ought to be worth $75 or $80. He would make a good team horse and the spring halt would not hurt him for teaming. With love to each. hoping to hear from you tonight stating when you are coming. Wish you were here so I could visit with you while I am sick. Hope to see you very soon however. Your brother, Edward.
Completed

Turin, April 6, 1883, 

Dear Sisters 

  Yours of the 28th ult. is still unanswered and it is time for us to have another letter from you but we cannot expect one until that one is answered.  have written to John Eddie answering his questions &c. I received a P.O. Order for $19.85 from Rev. R. Pierce, Long Creek in payment for books and I have paid your bill at W.P. Wms $12.75 and the balance I hold in my hands expecting to get more to send with it to you. Thos. R. Evans promises to pay the $80 in about a week and when it is paid I will send it to you.
Completed

When Mate got up yesterday morning she was all broken out with mock measals or Roseola.  The Missionary Meeting was appointed to be at our house yesterday but as the roads are impassable for horses there was no one there from out of the village and most of those who came did not stay as they were afraid they might catch it. Rev. Mr. Webber came out Wed. eve to attend the prayer meeting on foot and staid to attend the funeral of the father of Wm. B. Jones who works for Mrs. Cadwell Dewey, today. He came to the Miss. Meeting but did not stay. No one staid to tea but Mrs. Bowe and Mary Roberts. Mate is some better today. Last Monday when Mate was washing she missed Robbie and found him on his way up stairs on the fourth step. The next day after she had baked two tins of ginger bread and put them away on the shelf in the pantry she missed him again and this time found him with one little fist full of the cake out of each tin enjoying himself first-rate. He is pretty well but worries a good deal cutting teeth. They have to take the mail to the
Completed

Falls on a hand sled as the roads are so high and soft that a horse cannot travel them. Last Tuesday was my birthday. It has been but a few short years since I was twenty. Ten years ahead from that standpoint seemed very long. But time sped on and I was thirty. The next ten years of my life is the sad part of my song. The greater part of our group have left us, and now I'm forty. Les the youngest of us all is growing old. This busy life will soon be passed but this thought should not cause us pain rightly use our time as it passes. I am glad you are enjoying yourselves so well and that you have plenty of oranges so cheap. I do not think it best for you to send us a box. I am afraid we could not use them before they would spoil. I did not see Rev. Mr. Morris of Bradford. I did not go there. He attended the Cymanfa at
Completed

Charleston Livga unclear and went home before the meeting at Blossburg. I was at the latter and then went to Charleston so I did not see him. I would like very much to become aquainted with Cousin Robert. Perhaps I may at some future time. The sidewalks from the house to the store are nearly all bare. It seems good to see the snow disapear so quietly. We have had no rain but it is wasting at top & bottom this mild sunny weather. Mrs. Lyman is some better. Mrs. Carter is also some better but has been very low for a long time. When I was at Long Creek, Iowa I saw a young lady about 18 years of age who had been sick and confind to her bed for about two years with spinal disease, much the same as sister Sarah. She had heard of Sarah's sickness and recovery and wanted to know if Dr. Strong is still living and if there is any help for her. I promised to write to you, Mary about her case and that you would know more about the treatment she had as you were with her. When I saw her, her face was bloated and she was very white or pale
Completed

Turin, June 13, 1883, Dear Sisters, I can hardly realize you are so near as we have heard so little from you. We are having so much rain that I suppose the work does not progress rapidly in the garden. It gives the weeds a good chance to start. I would like very much to spend a few days there with you, but suppose I cannot at present. Wish you would come and make us a visit after you get the garden started. Now the fare on the R.R. is reduced it will not cost as much as it did. When do you look for John Eddie. We are in telephone communication with
Completed

Constableville, Boonville, Rome, Houseville, Lowville, Port Leyden, Greig &c and expect soon to be on speaking terms with Remsen. The office here is in the Post office. Did Mary move and get settled before you left N.Y?I suppose you miss Tom. I see him pass nearly every day with the meat cart. Do you get good meat this summer? Jane drove out here a week ago last Friday and took Callie back with her on Monday. I suppose you have seen them. I did not know until then that she had been having a new wing put up in place of the old back wing. Have you been there yet? Shall we send the trunk to you by freight and what shall we put in it.
Completed

Does Mr. Richard make butter or send the milk to the factory? It is nearly mail time so I must close this now. We are all well. Robbie is quite well and growing. I think he has changed a good deal since you saw him. He wants to be out all the while when it is pleasant. He walks out on the piazza back and forth alone. He likes to have some one lead him out on the side-walk in front of the house to meet me when I come home to meals. The mosquittos have been making free plunder of his cheeks and forehead. Hope we shall have a letter from you soon. With much love, 
Edward.
Completed

Turin, June 30, 1883. Dear Sisters I have now received two full letters from Jennie and have only replied by postal cards but have intended to write you a letter sooner but something has hindered me so that I only had time to write a postal. We are always glad to get your letters and wish we might yet have a visit with you soon. Hope we may in the course of the summer. We should all enjoy it very much. Mate and the boys made you such a long visit last summer that we we would not expect to make
Completed

you a long visit this summer. They will be glad to spend a part of their vacation there. Their school closed yesterday. Carroll and Charlie passed in all their studies in the examination. Carroll passed 100 in Geography and Physical Geography and stood high in his other studies. They have gone down to their Uncle Jimmie's today strawberrying. Berries are quite plenty. Abbie and her children are down there and also her mother. Griff went to New York and Philadelphia Monday and expects to return tonight. Little Arthur has been sick for three or four days - he has a very sore mouth & is billious. Charlie is well and the other boys escaped without taking the mumps. Robbie is
Completed

quite worrisome. I think his eye teeth are troubling him. He is quite fleshy. He goes up stairs and out doors alone when allowed to do so. Am glad you are to have a visit from Cousin Mary. Wish we might have a visit from her soon. Hope she & Fanny will visit us this summer. I must close now to get this in the mail and finish what I have to say in another letter. With lots of love E.W.E. P.S. - What is sister Mary's address now?
Completed

Turin, June 22/83 Dear Sisters, Your good letter was welcomed last eve. I will write you a few lines this eve lest I fail to write tomorrow morning as I did this morn. Thank you for writing so much news. Charlie has had the mumps quite light. He is nearly well. The others have not come down yet. Abbie & her family are with us, also mother Allen. Griff & Abbie, and Mate have been to hear Mrs. Margaret Jones lecture at Music Hall, and have just gone home. Am sorry you cannot go with us to B. Lake but perhaps it would be too tiresome for Anna to go with so many children. Perhaps there will be a chance to go again. Robbie is a great heavy boy. Love from E.W.E.
Completed

Turin,  July 25 / 83
Dear Sisters
What do you decide about going to B-ham?  The past few days has been rather cool for such a place but it is some warmer this A.M.  Think we will have some fine weather now.  Mate and the children went under the hill yesterday morning to stay tow or three days and pick Red raspberries &c.  They are very plenty there.  I am keeping house alone.  The blackberry crop looks very promising.  Hope you an all come up here to enjoy them in their season.  Has Mr. Prichard finished haying?  Is J.E. still at Fremonts?  We want to see you all.  Write often.  Love from your brother.     E.W.E.
Completed

Turin, July 27, 1883, Dear Sister Jennie & all, Your postal came to hand about 8 o'clock last eve. We are very glad Mary and Anna are coming to make us a visit but do not want them to leave you behind and we will all enjoy the visit so much more if you come with them. Mate says "write to have Jennie come too, we have plenty of room for them all to sleep and a plenty to eat and a plenty of berries." Mate and the children are still at her brother's. I have taken advantage of her absence and painted the kitchen floor.  It looks much better and is most
Completed

dry. After closing the store last night I went down to tell them of your coming so they would be sure to come home today. They were intending to come this eve. They will stay and pick some more berries today so as to have some nice, fresh ones when you come. Jim is nearly through haying - has been very busy this week and was glad to have Mary's help to milk. Hope John Eddie can visit us when he gets through haying. The stage usually gets here at 8 or 8:30 P.M. so you will probably get here before dark. Now Jennie I hope you an arrange to come with them.  And then we an all be together to make
Completed

our plans to go to Brantingham if it is thought advisable. We received a postal from Emporia yesterday. They arrived safely at home on Saturday P.M. all well and not much fatigued. They found ripe peaches at Emporia. With love to all from your brother Edward.
Completed

Turin, Aug. 11, 1883, Dear Sister Anna & All We received your letter last eve with the fancy cards. They are very fine. Hope Charlie will have such a good time that he wont be homesick any more. Mr Williams and Pierce are talking of driving out to Steuben next week and if they go Dwight and Irving will go with them. The M.E. Sabbath School of Martinsburg have an Excursion to the Thousand Islands today. Fare from Glendale & return $1.30. Several have gone from here. Will Holden & Carrie, Byron Litchfield
Completed

and Lillie. Ev Prichard and Jennie and others. They drove to Glendale Started about 5-30 A.M. from here and take the regular train Mr. Cornish and family have gone with their team to visit friends near Rome. The farmers about here are making good use of their time this fine weather to finish their haying.Many stacks are being made. The crop is very heavy. Mr Cruikshank and family and some of their friends, making a large load report having a fine time at the Lake the day you went home. We are all well. Robbie was up at about half past five this morning. He has got a new pair of shoes. Hope we shall have a postal from the boys tonight.
Completed
Did they get their tooth brushes, and do they use them? Have the boys finished weeding the garden? We get four eggs every day now. Love to all from your brother Edward.
Completed

Turin, Aug. 27, 1883. Dear Sisters, I engaged a basket of berries of P. Bidinger's brother to be sent to Remsen on this evenings train by Express at 7 cts per qt. He lives at the Falls and brings nice berries to Turin every day. He took the basket. Do not know how many berries he will put in the basket. Let me know if they are nice. The boys left their tooth brushes there. Please send them by mail. Did Carroll leave an old coat? Mate & the three boys go to Jimmie's this A.M. The boys to pick hops. Robbie is not very well. Has the diarrhea but is some better. With love to all. E.W.E.
Completed

Turin,  Sept 4th / 83
Dear Sisters -- your postal came last eve.  There were 12 qts berries at 7 cts.  Will engage more for you and let you know when to look for them.  They continue to be very nice but the same price.  We feared we should have a frost this A.M. but had none.  Robbie has taken a little cold.  The boys went to school yesterday but today they are picking hops for Gen Carter back of the school house.  Maggie came down to our church to meeting last Sunday.  Her school closes some time next week.  Am sorry to hear that Mrs. Prichard does not improve faster.
Your brother.
E.W.E.
